channel.title: Last resort
channel.description:
My mums computer has completely fucked up. Whenever it boots, the following error comes up:
Windows could not start because the following file is missing or corrupt:
\windows\system\config\system
So, I insert the XP CD, however, I have no repair option....
I've searched the net everywhere with no help at all. Do I have to reformat? I have no back ups, but would use the System Recovery tool if it was available.
PLEASE HELP

item.title: Last resort
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Heh, it’s ok

Read full topic

item.title: Last resort
item.dc:creator: @Mr.Chris Mr.Chris
item.description:
@Mr.Chris wrote:

whoooaaaa sorry man. My bad, completely forgot to reply to it. thanks to you as well

Read full topic

item.title: Last resort
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:2, topic:231287”]Did you create that cd yourself when you booted it up for the first time? If you did, then it’s quite odd because I created a cd like that (I think it’s called a master cd) and I do have a repair option.

You can try to install Ubuntu as a dual boot and somehow download the missing/corrupted file and manually place it where it should be. But maby there is a faster way of repairing it.[/quote]

Wowow nobody listens to me lately.

Read full topic

item.title: Last resort
item.dc:creator: @Mr.Chris Mr.Chris
item.description:
@Mr.Chris wrote:

Did it through the Live CD. No need to even install! <3 Ubuntu. TYVM Bank

Read full topic

item.title: Last resort
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

OR, Install linux as a duel boot and mount your xp partition so you can move the files yourself. Then delete linux if you want.

Read full topic

item.title: Last resort
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

boot from the microsoft CD, (download from torrent or rapidshare) and enter recovery console, and type:

copy c:\windows\repair\system c:\windows\system32\config\system copy c:\windows\repair\software c:\windows\system32\config\software copy c:\windows\repair\sam c:\windows\system32\config\sam copy c:\windows\repair\security c:\windows\system32\config\security copy c:\windows\repair\default c:\windows\system32\config\default

OR try a second repair, which is basically re-install windows over itself (i.e. replacing all files and load defaults etc etc)

Read full topic

item.title: Last resort
item.dc:creator: @Mr.Chris Mr.Chris
item.description:
@Mr.Chris wrote:

xEnt:

is your boot priority set to CD first? check/change in your bios.

The CD works exactly how it should. I can get to the installation on a new partition, but before that, it should check for previous Windows, and it doesn’t find it.

Read full topic

item.title: Last resort
item.dc:creator: @Mr.Chris Mr.Chris
item.description:
@Mr.Chris wrote:

It’s a proper Windows installation CD, however, I’ve heard Dells and HPs and the like are notorious for not being able to perform this option. I’m torrenting a program called ERD Commander to see if that will help repair. If not, looks like I’ll be formatting.

Read full topic

item.title: Last resort
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Did you create that cd yourself when you booted it up for the first time? If you did, then it’s quite odd because I created a cd like that (I think it’s called a master cd) and I do have a repair option.

You can try to install Ubuntu as a dual boot and somehow download the missing/corrupted file and manually place it where it should be. But maby there is a faster way of repairing it.

Read full topic
